unit_learning_outcomes.description: Solve problems in both static and dynamic systems.
Demonstrate proficiency in applying mathematical knowledge to solve fundamental engineering dynamic problems.
Perform structural analysis of three-dimensional machine frames and structures.
Demonstrate proficiency in the presentation of introductory level mechanical engineering solutions.

enrolment_rules.description: (PHYS1510 or PHYS140) and (MATH135 or MATH132 or MATH1010 or MATH1015)

assessments.description: There will be four online quizzes, each worth 7.5%. The quiz will be open for a specific time and all students must take the quiz during that time. All students are to ensure that they have their own resources (Computers, tablet, smart phone etc) to take part in the quiz.

There will be two assignments, each worth 10%. A portion of the available grades will be awarded for presentation of work. Markers WILL NOT grade poorly organized or illegible scans or drafts. Well presented work is highly legible, annotated, well structured, and presented with page numbers and student IDs on every page.
This is a hurdle assessment task. The final exam will be hurdle assessment task testing mechanical concepts.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Special circumstances
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances
data.description: The unit introduces the broad field of Mechanical engineering concepts. It will cover fundamental mechanics knowledge that is required to analyse forces in both static and dynamic physical system and also to perform fundamental fluid mechanics analysis. At the end of the unit, students are expected to demonstrate the ability to analyse and solve basic mechanics problems fluently.
data.title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering

description: The unit introduces the broad field of Mechanical engineering concepts. It will cover fundamental mechanics knowledge that is required to analyse forces in both static and dynamic physical system and also to perform fundamental fluid mechanics analysis. At the end of the unit, students are expected to demonstrate the ability to analyse and solve basic mechanics problems fluently.
title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
